J0lTwvhKSK-HVYW0JxMijw.text: I really should have read other Yelp reviews before coming here. All the comments about the sub-par service were spot on! I'm sure the staff meant well but wow, the service was sooo sloooowwww. I estimate that it took the waiter 10 minutes to take our order, another 30 minutes to serve us our food and then 20 minutes to give us our bill after we asked for it...twice! Besides the fact that our dinner took about three hours, the food was delicious and spicy. I got the spring rolls to start and the barbeque chicken on rice with a nice selection of sauces. The mean left me satisfied but the service left much to be desired...

vv2itXAgkspSuRixtWuSVQ.text: Good, solid Malay cuisine for fans of heavy spices. Rich & funky sambal, tasty Kangkong, garlic fried chicken... you name it. Don't go for the ambiance or the service - just go for the food. Better yet, get takeaway and enjoy it at home (but your car will never smell the same again). I think it's run by Singaporeans, so the menu's a bit of a medley - but they are foodies at heart.

YUBsBwPl0Y1rtZDiq9VnHA.text: I am a malaysian food lover. The cuisine is rich in flavors, and is spicy and hot which is one of my favorites. We ordered a coupld of signature dishes to be shared, and if you are going there, you must try their famous 'teh tarik'. It's milk tea served with condensed milk. May not be the taste for everyone as some may consider it to be too sweet. ANother 'must try' dish is 'Rendang'. It's their signature dish.

XI6Xt4Z1iuADEMmElx2YoQ.text: I had this restaurant recommended to me by my friend and I am glad I went. The service was friendly and prompt, the food was full of rich and authentic Malaysian flavours and it was great value for money. I will definitely be passing it on as a recommendation to my friends!

V6i4PEckT0M7ICkCKKcRLQ.text: I had dined here years, possibly decades ago and never returned. However, as I was in the area on Saturday, I decided to give it another go.Firstly, although its name is Satay House and they do offer satay as a starter, it isn't a restaurant which specialises in satay. It does offer a good mix of mainly Malaysian food with some Indonesian thrown in. Certainly the kitchen staff speak Malay - a good sign in my book.As it was raining, I stood under the restaurant awning. I was there at 10 to 6 and the staff saw me and left me there until 6. They then gave me the 'Do you have a reservation? Oh you don't (sigh) Let me check" routine. Very irritating when you're standing in a completely empty restaurant at opening time.Over the next 90 minutes, only 2 more groups arrived and they were both given the same routine. A tip to restauranteurs - unless you're el Bulli and get booked solid for the next 6 months on the day that reservations open for the season, please learn to make your customers feel welcome. Customer service 101.Anyway rant over and I perused the yummy looking menu. I then had to try to attract the attention of the waitresses who were loudly discussing the personal life of one of them. Interesting to listen to in a 'News of the World' kind of way but I think my loudly growling tummy eventually persuaded one of them to come over to take my order.She was honest enough to say that the soya bean drink was out of a carton so I opted for watermelon juice instead. It was lovely and refreshing if a bit pricey at £3.30.I had spied that they offered roti canai with onion and egg, making it the first place that I'd seen it offered in London. Lots of places offer it but without the onion and egg. When it arrived, my heart leapt at seeing a proper square roti canai. Everywhere else that serves it has given me round ones, which look suspiciously like the frozen ones that I buy from the Chinese supermarket. This roti canai was definitely freshly made and if a little stingy with the onion filling, tasted just like the ones from Malaysia. I didn't think the vegetable dalca they served with it really did the bread justice and on my next visit, I'm going to ask if they can let me have some proper curry sauce to go with it.For my main course, I went with the curry noodles and this dish lives or dies by the quality of the curry soup in which all the other ingredients are sitting. Well, I'm very glad to report that it had a wonderful rich, rounded, deep flavour. There were generous amounts of chicken and prawns along with the noodles and vegetables. Most delicious.By the end of the meal, 4 serving staff had arrived. The Malay-speaking girl was the only one to make an effort with the guests. Just a shame that some of her other colleagues didn't really raise much of a smile. In fact, the male waiter had about as much warmth as a polar bear's bum which had been sitting on an ice block for a day.However, the food was lovely and I'll be back to try more dishes. Just hope they're sent their waiting staff to charm school by then

a2HCvllltKjFw3DyShjDrQ.text: This is a great restaurant to start with if you don't know much about Satay. It is always busy due to due the value for money and the smart decor (a 2006 makeover by the designers responsible for the Gourmet Burger Kitchen and  Wagamama) and had been in operation for almost 40 years. The decor is very simple: cream, brown and white interior with the odd orchid plant here and there. The main emphasis is on the quality of the food. It'll come as no surprise that my favourite dish here is lamb satay skewers, marinated in spices and herbs (6 for £6.10) but I also recommend the Chicken Nasi Campur curry with MurtabakBread (filled with minced lamb, egg and served with pickled onions and dalca). The drinks too, are just as unusual. Malaysian lychee and melon juice make great mixers for the full bar of spirits.

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom

t9-ep4WX7U1riJHaUG9ftg.text: We went as a couple. The place is decent look with good ambience and crowd. The food however was just par. Everything in general was a little too sweet which is not what i associate malaysian food with. Most of the food was also lacking in seasoning. The satay was ok, laksa was decent without being special. The roti however was good. Portions were decent. Service was a little slow but they were courteous. They were apologetic when they got the order wrong and offered a free drink. Dinner for 2 with a glass of wine came to around 50£

4lUfri20wPvgzZ_jWBnfaA.text: Love this place. Great food, very convenient for Paddington. I've been back several times, and I'll be back again.

vFGGDRnnkUd1iJQbNGwqTw.text: Really good Malaysian . I recommend the sambal fish, and the chicken satay!

iPLKCNVUjL3nHqiKcwqWcQ.text: I remember first reading about this place as one that apparently the Prime Minister of Malaysia used to come and eat at when visiting town. It also happens to feature quite frequently in the listings in Time Out magazine. It looks small on the outside, and you can tell they've put in as many as tables as they could without making it too uncomfortable. The top floor entrance seemed buzzing with people, and with our 8:30pm booking, we ended up downstairs where it was a little bit less frenzied and a bit more relaxed. Large teardrop lightings fill the olive green painted walls with warmth with the dark brown square tables providing a sharp contrast to the dining atmosphere. They even had a more intimate dining 'alcove' downstairs which we saw one party fill, complete with mini teardrop downlights and black pseudo-leather couches. Compared to a lot of other places, I have to say that their menu all looked really tempting and it was pretty hard to stay focused without being distracted by all they had to offer. Their menu is organised around rice, noodle, sides, chicken, beef, fish, prawn, vegetable and for those who can't make up their minds, a series of different set menus matching both appetite and budget (£15.50 - £26.50) All of their dishes really impressed me and I thought worth the little bit more that they charge. The very simple Nasi Aayam (steamed chicken with rice served with soy and chilli sauce) remained thoroughly moist and flavourful, even without the dipping sauces. The satay sticks had their perfect amount of smokiness, and also remained moist with the only downside being the peanut sauce not being as spicy as I would have liked it (and understanding that it typically isn't that spicy). I also liked the fact that their mee goreng (friend noodles) contained plenty of flavour and not just soy sauce as evident from the heat given off from whatever chilli paste they used throughout it. The only fault I can really give this restaurant was the rather lack lustre service that was never in your face yet, nor was it particularly attentive when you did want something.

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Satay House
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom

z9p5aOPkX8ZCR-pknz_0-w.text: Great, authentic Malaysian food (Malay cuisine). A bit expensive by Malaysian standards, but really excellent.

mMwhZjIeljt6-g-RAri15A.text: Satay House - Pics at The London Foodie (thelondonfoodie.co.uk/20… ) I am enjoying the 2010 Malaysian Kitchen Campaign a great deal. The opportunity to find out more about one of the most fascinating but relatively undiscovered Asian cuisines (and eat a lot of it in the process), right here in London, is an opportunity not to be missed. I was lucky enough to have been involved in this campaign for the launch of the Malaysian Dining Card at Kiasu (reviewed here), and more recently as part of a Malaysian restaurant tour which included Awana, Satay House and Tukdin. The event was organised to showcase what these restaurants will be offering at the Malaysian Section of this year's Taste of London Festival. We were whisked away to our next stop, Satay House in Paddington. The restaurant is small and casual with a modern feel about it. Our first round of main courses was served at this delightful restaurant, and in my opinion, one of the most successful dishes was the Udang Galah Goreng (king prawns fried in turmeric, chillies, lime leaves and coconut milk). The prawns were meaty but still soft and their richness was offset by the lime's citric flavours and the delicate coconut milk. The Rendang Daging (slow cooked beef in spices, herbs and coconut milk) was also noteworthy. I enjoyed the rich flavours of cinnamon, cloves and star anise infused in the very tender meat. I love aubergines and so quite enjoyed Terong Goreng Berlada (aubergines stir-fried with ground chillies and shrimps) despite feeling that it was a little overspiced. Less successful dishes were the Satay (chicken and lamb skewers served with a peanut sauce) and the Kway Teow Goreng (stir-fried flat rice noodles with seafood, egg and vegetables). The former was slightly on the tough side whereas the noodles lacked the delicious combination of flavours that I have experienced from this dish elsewhere.

dqspuxQrtjd5se1QrwOk6A.text: My husband and I went for my birthday, because I love Malaysian flavours and this restaurant seemed to have good ratings. We left quite disappointed.The service was abominable. The spring roll starter was generic at best; its sauce was the only redeeming factor. My Gado Gado was tasty, primarily if not wholly because of the sauce/dressing. My husband did not enjoy his curry, complaining that the chicken was of poor quality. He didn't finish it, which is unlike him and must mean it was truly poor (as a vegetarian, I didn't taste it myself).We received our food about thirty minutes after the people next to us received theirs, and they arrived at the restaurant at least 30 minutes after we did. We sat and waited for what seemed like forever before we could catch the eye of a server to request the bill. We then waited for at least 15 minutes to receive it and another 15 minutes to pay with a credit card. Although we arrived at a generally early dining hour, we left so late that I was worried the tube might have closed.

EHPnAl5gcY5ekILnbPgkWg.text: Excellent Malaysian food, and the staff was very friendly.  I thought their basement seating arrangement was very nice and cozy.

glKBcwcO3upardoRhO2SyQ.text: the best malaysian restaurant. Food taste so delicious - the aroma tickles your appetite - and the service is first class  definitely would revisit again

sS1reQW5g3O5b1rNZQ93og.text: I went here for the first time last night for my good friends birthday - she loves everything Malay! boy was i STARVING when i arrived early thus i ordered a starter (squid) to keep me going til the rest arrived.... this starter arrived an hour late - after everyone had ordered and after we received our other starters... (apparently it went to the wrong table!) but still... Bar that slight debarcle, it was amazing food, well presented, good flavours and well priced and we all loved it! definately going back!

kGFPvg_8lh-S0oByGAaHxg.text: The day I went to Satay House is one of the more memorables of my last trip to London. I Googled for Singaporean and Malaysian places, and Satay House ended up being the most highly recommended one that I hadn't been to. Read somewhere that the prime minister of Malaysia comes here when he's in London (disclaimer: don't know if it's true, but I could definitely believe it).I had just a few days in London, and many of the meals were taken up by friends. I actually had lunch plans on this day already, meeting up at Notting Hill. I decided I would take two lunches that day and headed out to Paddington for the earlier lunch. Took a bit of searching as I'm not familiar with the area and the sign isn't very conspicuous. Walked in, and heard Malay being spoken at the tables. Of all the languages you hear walking around London, Malay's not at the top of the list. This was a Good Sign.The waitress was blond(!) but spoke Malay (!!) with the other customers. I ordered their trademark nasi lemak. It was a bit of a risk, because honestly, I've never been impressed by nasi lemak outside of Singapore/Malaysia. Further sceptical because it had shrimp, instead of fish or chicken. Then it came, and the portion looked a little on the small side. Hmm.In the first bite or two, I actually wasn't sure I'd be able to eat the whole thing, it was so spicy. I don't think I've ever eaten something that spicy in a restaurant, and I'm not sure I've ever made something that spicy intentionally. And I adore spicy food. I believe there's no dish that can't be made better by adding black pepper/white pepper/chili flakes/chili sauce/fresh cut chilis/jalapenos/Tabasco sauce, etc. Just pick your poison. Anyway, after the initial shock, my taste buds adapted, and the nasi lemak was a total food orgasm. Not necessarily your traditional nasi lemak (shrimp and all), but the combination of flavours and textures with the rice, peanuts, and ikan bilis were just divine.I finished it all, and couldn't have eaten another bite. Turned out to be the perfect portion size. I paid the bill quickly and went to Notting Hill, wondering how I was going to explain that I was full going into lunch. Well, luckily I didn't have to worry about that, because there were massive and hilarious miscommunications due to a friend who still didn't have a mobile phone. We ended up looking for each other for more than an hour, then walked a good way to a bog-standard pub, by which point I actually was a little hungry again.Conclusion: Satay House = win.

slGuvJbPEr6wn5LoL_qu2g.text: Tasty Malaysian fare in a pretty restaurant.

Tu41IWN25o3_4rS4DAAn6Q.text: This is my favourite "Malay" Malaysian restaurant in London (compared to others e.g. Mawar (now Melur), Naha (now Bonda), Jom Makan, etc). These are different to the "Chinese" Malaysian restaurants (e.g. C&R, Kopitiam, Rasa Sayang) that serve food which is more influenced by the chinese (e.g. noodles, soy sauce, soup-based).The food here is authentic Malay, and was set up in the 1970s by a Malay couple from Perak, and their daughter now runs the place. When I lived near the area a few years back, I would go there at least once a week. My favourite dishes are kari kambing (lamb curry), rendang, ayam berlada, ikan berlada, sotong berempah, as these are some of their spicier/tastier dishes. Their sambal is authentic, but too expensive at £4.50 for a small thimble (about 50ml).Kari kambing (goat curry) - very nice goat curry, with a woody curry flavour. The meat can be a bit gamey, but that's what u get with goat. Another reviewer mentioned it tasted more indian than east asian, which is true, because 5%-10% of malaysians are Indian and that's where most of the spicier dishes in Malaysia (Malay or Chinese) have come from. You get plenty of curry in a bowl, which is slightly watery, but great for eating with rice.Rendang (slow-cooked beef in a dry spicy sauce) - most of my Malaysian friends love this dish as their favourite (I still prefer the goat curry), as it is a ridiculously authentic version of the rendang you find in Malaysia. The beef really is slow cooked, so that it comes apart, rather than pieces of beef which I find most other restaurants serve. The flavour is deep and rich, and there is plenty of dry sauce to eat with ur rice.Ayam berlada (chilli fried chicken) - pieces of chicken that are deep fried first (so there is an outer crispy coating), and then fried with onions and chilli flakes. Be warned, there is a lot of oil with this dish.Ikan berlada (chilli fried fish) - dry fried pieces of chunky fish, with chilli flakes and loads of onions (sometimes I do find the onions a bit too much). Even though it's similarly named to the chicken version above, the fish version doesn't come swimming in oil.Sotong berempah (squid with spices) - pieces of squid cooked with curry leaves and other spices. This dish also has loads of oil. The portion is also a bit smaller than the others.Ayam percik (bbq chicken) - this version comes served with a creamy, slightly sweet sauce (most Malaysians will know ayam percik as the bbq chicken they get from the pasar malam/night market, which is dry). The chicken doesn't appear to be heavily bbq-ed (doesn't have strong grill marks), so I would guess it's been very lightly grilled. It's good for people who can't take very spicy food.For dessert, I usually go for their pisang goreng (fried banana fritters), which comes with ice cream and/or syrup. I used to like their ice kacang, but it now comes in a glass, which I find difficult to eat from. I preferred when they served it in a bowl. Their sago is good, and so is their cendol.Note: As a Malaysian, we don't typically go for starters, so I cannot comment on their spring rolls. I have tried their satay, which is good. Their begedil is average.In terms of "anglicised" dishes, which one reviewer mentioned, I feel this is true of their ayam masak merah and ayam percik. However, the other dishes I have described above are truly authentic Malaysian dishes. If anyone wants to try authentic Malay Malaysian food, I recommend their rendang and ayam berlada with rice, along with the kangkong belacan.

ackNQSYAzjK83YXndIXwkw.text: Excellent Malaysian food and service. It's always busy and worth booking in advance. We paid £45 for 3 people which we considered as a good price. Book a table downstairs. Can't fault it.

l1iw88uLyeY5BxqGZ7gapA.text: Had a Malaysian FEAST at Satay House with a gaggle of foodie girls during a recent trip to London. We're all about the sharing, so bits of nasi lemak, roti canai (we re-ordered, sooo good), tom yum soup, beef rendang, tahu sumbat and kway teow goreng flew around our little table.Everything was wonderful; fresh, flavourful, spicy. I ordered the nasi lemak on the recommendation of my best friend, who said she had really enjoyed it before. It turned out she hadn't had it there at all, but at another place, and when it arrived I was skeptical that I'd made the right choice.The various ingredients laid out on the plate (rice, cucumber, prawn curry, dried anchovies, peanuts, hard boiled egg) looked a little colourless and forlorn, not the spicy Malaysian melange I'm used to. I dove in and mixed them together though, and soon realized the error of my ways. The dish was delicious, and something I would definitely order again.

LuAbmNkdUB9kOXN6xLDnjg.text: This place is worth a try! The food was really delicious. It was my first attempt at Malaysian food and I was not disappointed. Don't ask me to remember the name of the dish I chose though, I've absolutely no clue. All I know is that the place is small but with a warn atmosphere, the chicken skewers as a starter were yummy and my lamb spicy dish was to expectations. Pity though that you feel rushed all the way as they're trying to get 2/3 sittings in a 2h time frame.

a_1BUjG05G-F8YoznOXr1g.text: malay food is not that well represented in my experience. This restaurant, however had a friendly feel and I had a set menu which was plenty of food. Each course delicately spiced and very tasty. It felt homely and authentic and was a very enjoyable meal .if you are in the area and fancy some spice this place is a must but booking may be advisable as it was busy on a Sunday night

aho_xXJSpVDDSI1iWXgvsA.text: Satay House is an established Malaysian restaurant (having been around for at least 30 years) and was all buzzy when we arrived at 8.30 this evening. Whether its urban myth or not even the Malaysian Prime Minister used to frequent this restaurant when he was in town. The Satay House has a decent selection of Malaysian food though quite a bit pricier than other restaurants I've been to. It was pretty late so we didn't eat too much sticking with chicken satay skewers, Mee Goreng (our test dish for all things Malaysian) and Nasi Ayam (which is a fairly simple steamed chicken with rice cooked in chicken broth.) Strangely what was lacking tonight was the service. It was friendly when we finally got some attention but the waiter seemed more interested in making conversation with diners who had finished their meals and clearing tables than in taking our order. It was almost condescending how he would nod at us as if to say yes I acknowledge you are there but I will not actually serve you anyway. I don't want to let one waiter turn me off from the Satay House because to be honest good Malaysian restaurants in London are few and far in between. Prices for the services you get are a bit higher than average but I guess that's to cover the recent update that the restaurant has gone (apparently by the designers behind GBK and Wagamama.) Good atmosphere but be warned that tables are very close to each other so be prepared to hear the conversation on both sides of you and for them to hear yours! Good Malaysian  at a price.

hH399I9xwV3unJupvrxt6A.text: Satay!! The basement is nice and cozySerious, meh, I've experienced better...

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Chicken was good. Lamb too gamely
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Food was meh

nsnoNfFyDxpKaOw1DD25vA.text: Some of the best food we've had in London. The service was great and the food was very very good! I had the fried rice with meat and shrimp and the rice was just perfect. Although the noise level was quite loud due to a large group our dining experience was still great. I would definitely recommend this restaurant!

BMHptGooIRS7l66UUSOXcw.text: Service was barley OK, food was dry and taste less. There is a bunch of other places in the area, spend 15 minutes to find another place.

6PE_QnqDCZ8x7HZmo-pJnA.text: This was one of the best finds during our most recent London trip.I highly recommend this spot which was around the corner from the Hilton Metropole Hotel.We had two kinds of Satay skewers to start, then had some malaysian beef curry and a Mee GorengThe food was fresh and very authentic. Try the Air Bandung for a refreshing drink!There was a steady stream of people in and out of this place including a number of people that came for take out.The staff were friendly and efficient.In our estimation, one of the best restaurants in this area!

h6kxk2dTCZW8CVUUDBN0PQ.text: London is seriously lacking when it comes to good Indonesian food, and so I often come here. I hadn't been in a while, though, so when I went again last week for a friend's birthday I was surprised by a few changes. Although overall the food was still good, the portion sizes had shrunk even as the prices had gone up. Also, none of the staff seemed to be Malaysian (not that that's important) or know what they were serving. The curry of the roti canai was slightly lumpy and too thick in my opinion, but the rendang was still great. The pajeri terong (aubergine curry) was particularly tasty.Our main grudge with the place on this occasion, however, was the service. The waitress wasn't particularly friendly to us, and a couple of times forgot our order and said it was because we had failed to place them (our table of five disagreed). Maybe she (or the five of us) were having an off day, but it might be a while until I go back, even though I love the food.

sQGWoq4g8SeFSO_fdsQTJg.text: One thing I love about London, as a Chinese-Malaysian, is the great abundance of Malaysian food wherever one looks.I had been sick (see my previous review for Wagamama) and needed a late dinner after sleeping my sickness off for the second time in the day. By this time all the pubs had stopped serving food. Only Satay House was still open and accepting customers (and they kept coming in even after we sat down!)I had a bowl of curry laksa which hit the spot for under 10 quid. The service was fast and friendly too. I can't complain and wish I had such a place near me in Manhattan.

KRb4xTPrP2vtUB5srwcHug.text: Even though I'm living in Hong Kong now, every time my boyfriend and I talk about London and our time there we conclude we have to go back there sometime, to London and to Satay House. It was my boyfriend who found it, he's a good restaurant hunter and always discovered amazing places. This was located close (for London standards) to my place. We used to eat in the basement, tiny and usually full. I think we've tried pretty much everything there including the Satay skewers, the Rendang beef, the coated prawns and...Pisang Goreng, a dessert that blew our mind: fried banana accompanied by vanilla/dark chocolate ice cream (a bit of a treat for my taste). Seriously, if a place stays in your mind this way it's because it was remarkable. Yeah, it's remarkable. I'll go back when in London. So looking forward to it!

qF2lONI9S_KFqVs5f2JmVw.text: Authentic Malaysian food, with a surprisingly big menu than one would expect, especially since Malaysian food is sometimes very time consuming to prepare in the kitchen, especially the sauces and curries.Service was quick, the restaurant was nice and bright. Tables are not too close together, and its down a quiet street near Paddington station and Edgware Road station.FOod was authentic. Roti Canai was made well. The sauce was a bit too watery though for my liking. The lamb curry was nice  the mutton was tender. Ice Kacang for dessert is recommended  as is the banana fritters with ice cream.Price-wise, its slightly pricey for the portion sizes.

HO-jgAuY27HaECedaemcQw.text: Visiting London brother advised must eat here, went last night over an hour wait. So we decided to go to Edgeware road and have Lebanese. So we made reservations to have lunch today which was a good decision as they where not that busy. We order several dishes and then some bread or pharata which were excellent. Must try when in London. It's a light meal not heavy like the Indian curry places. Enjoy the satay !

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. The menu and details

7J3tpR90WNi0ckXaKqqXiQ.text: My fiance is Malaysian, so we have tried most reputable Malaysian restaurants in London.  This is by far our favourite.  The ambiance is casual, but the food is as good as you'll find in the city. A few things on the menu don't stand out (for example, I wish that the roti was crispier), but the vast majority of staples are expertly executed.  I always get the kari laksa (pure, warm coconut and seafood goodness) and cap it off with a delicious Teh Tarik.  The finance gets the nasi lemak, nasi goreng, or mee goreng.  Fortunately, he always shares.  The people who work here are friendly and always welcome regulars, so it a great go to when you want a laid back evening with solid food. Just make sure to call ahead.  A lot of time the kitchen is busy as they also do takeaway orders.

-zQE4fkPXkq0iQF0O2gwXg.text: Satay 6 skewers of char-grilled chicken- Juicy and seasoned well with just the right amount of char.Mee Goreng Sayur Stir-fried egg noodles with egg, tofu, sliced tomatoes and vegetables- Way too salty and not much veggies.Ayam Percik Grilled chicken cooked in creamy coconut milk and spices- Probably my favorite dish of everything we tried. Rich and delicious sauce!Roti Canai with egg and onion- A bit too thick and soggy for my taste

vbRwyYwEmnMGjnpQ27R3yw.text: Absolutely delicious food!I've been here a few times and the food is always fantastic - especially the squid!Service seemed faster in the upstairs area and downstairs can get quite stuffy.This is a fantastic place to come with a group in order to try as many of the amazing small dishes as possible.

5KtiSS1Bw_sk6wfNmHLDMA.text: I ate here some years ago and liked it quite a bit. This time was disappointing.  The sauce for the roti canai was a light liquid and nothing like the usual thick curry I get in MY or other restaurants. Generally lack of spicing that evening. In spite of asking for some, only one dish had any and it only just registered.  Very in-authentic...Credit to them for being ready to answer my query about their Laksa, saying that it is from Johor and quite different from others, such as Penang or even Singapore; sounded as if they don't use tamarind at all. Alas, also had to avoid gluten and fish -- and all sea creatures, just to be safe -- to avoid risks for a party member; a shame, of course.Lamb Curry was roasted, spicy chops and was the only interesting and good dish of the evening.I always order ABC for newcomers to Malaysian food.  Was ok here, but not great.

Ll683igdYWi3FEoQmmqhjw.text: Very nice place! The chicken curry was delicious, but would be better if rice were included and not a la carte. The chicken satay was a kid-pleaser - always a good thing. Great ambiance. Highly recommended for tasty Malaysian fare!

KDQco6-mw6pEu0SJTasH-w.text: Very nice service and delicious food! Everything is fantastic! I strongly recommend it to all of you!

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom

O6V0OxGX5_kElWRRCDDvCA.text: This is a really nice Malaysian restaurant in Paddington. It's a little more expensive than say, Rasa Sayang, but the food is tasty, portions are big and the atmosphere is relaxing.They have all the usual Malaysian dishes, the satay sauce is really good, as are most dishes. I had the Nasi Campur - tasty and hot! Recommend if you are in the area.

oRczHwO22xGQDnPXlX6GMQ.text: Im malaysian and miss malaysian food so badly.. this is the place to be man... authentic! i had nasi lemak and teh tarik.. sedapppp- which means very tasty!

pzDVybTHo3qTkJMXzL3iSg.text: Came back four years later and everything was amazing. The spice level, the flavors, the balance and texture. This is the only Malay place I tried in UK but it's so good I don't care to even try others.

qf6kzQ-nrGqHEcIxN5lMbg.text: Have come here a few times and now it's time to write about how much I like this place! Ambiance: none. Service: friendly, reasonably quick in my experience. Difference from the mad crush of the Paddington environs: tremendous.  Child friendly? No, says yelp. Yes, say my kids.  Who you gonna trust?As some reviewers have noted, the chicken is sub par. Actually, I like it but it is thigh meat and most rarefied yelping palates I reckon prefer breasts.  Still, stay away and have the tremendously good fish or beef rendang. The bread (roti canai) is also great.  A bit on the pricey side perhaps, but definitely worth it, and not just after a train ride back from a weekend's pub trekking in Devon (but then especially).

76RG9D277Q1tjxgAhbZgpQ.text: Very good Malaysian restaurant run by a second-generation British Malaysian. Good ambience, friendly staff. Considering its neighbourhood, the prices are very reasonable (approx. £ 15 per head including service fee). The Nasi Lemak is way to spicy for me, but its satay and Kari Laksa won't let you down.

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Kari Laksa.
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Nasi Lemak. Hooo, it's spicy.
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Satay

9cIIEb8cTigUmkN-o4_-9Q.text: On a quiet side street near Paddington Station is a great Maylasian restaurant. That sounded like I know Malaysian food. Let's say a great restaurant. I know nasi goreng and... that's it. If there were more diners, I would have pointed to what they has ordered. Luckily, the unfamiliar names of food had an English tagline. That helped a lot. My adventuresomeness stopped after an appetizer of udang tepung, fried anchovies with crunchy peanuts and chili powder appetizer (way better than it sounds). I was flummoxed  for the entree. Luckily, the young waiter was used to babes in the jungle. I said spicy and rice and what do you recommend? Out comes a dish of ayam masak lemak cilli cipi. It was a coconut based thin curry. Looked a lot like the Thai tom ka gai, with pieces of grilled chicken -- with one fresh, very hot, red chili. Two Singha beers required to put out the flames.

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Udang tepung is fried anchovies, crunchy peanuts and lotd of chilli powder.
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Menu.  Drink menu not shown.

c7zJUU3J_Q29dAfF_y2oQQ.text: Pros:1) Good service2) Looks cleanCons:1) Small portion, hence over price for what you get2) Food average for Malaysian standard

q5_IwVimU_4Ri9YZWF2Slg.text: I ordered Mie goreng. It was good i had the sago desert which i also really liked. It was very expensive though (compared to us food prices). Food is halal.

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Sago desert
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Mie goreng

lNZ00LMXTLL0Lb7I6nZuxQ.text: We stayed in Hilton Metropole and it is only 5 mins walk to here. Food is tasty and service is great!

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom

7elgAqvBXLDeMjP4Qcuo-g.text: Really enjoyed this wholesome food and great service. Really surprised me as to how tasty the food was.

D-MHu6hVvA82gCyKQBRosA.text: Great restaurant. Came here with a couple people, we shared, and I was very impressed by everything that came our way. If you're in the Paddington area and feel like something a little different, give this a try - we'll worth the 5 minute walk.

VKTE-HthzyZqyq04SXE8-Q.text: Amazing beef satay, although the chicken curry was hard to beat! Banana fritters with coconut ice cream was

EMHvtWGrbtUXAWANZZOtgw.text: Rasa Sayang Satay House, Paddington - not often we feast on Malaysian food in restaurants because of my Malaysian Home Cooking Supperclub. Most of the time I am also occupied with trying out new recipes, dishes and flavours. Tweaking it to perfection before making sure the dish is good enough for my supperclub. But, that is not to say that we don't eat Malaysian food in restaurants, just hardly ever. I need to keep myself informed. We feasted at Rasa Sayang Satay House restaurant upon the invitation from Contact Singapore. At the gathering, there were about 40, mostly young professionals, working in London in the accountancy and finance sector.Rasa Sayang restaurant is tiny. It is split into two floors. Nothing fancy. Just a simple dining place. Parking a pram in the restaurant space is also quite challenging. The dishes were already decided and I did not have a chance to look at the menu but you can be sure that Malaysian favourite noodle dishes such as the char kuay teow and curry laksa are on the menu.Overall, the food was generally quite good but I would have thought that on this occasion, being a special Malaysian gathering, the dishes would have the extra spice and kick and not the usual flavours as when vatering for the western public. The general agreement amongst the diners were that the ayam masak merah was not a teeny bit spicy and the prawn sambal could have had chilli heat.

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. prawn sambal
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. lamb curry
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. ayam masak merah (chilli in red hot sauce)

ADx8UPw2iisUwJ8EpLbPoA.text: All good.  Liked the flavor/spices.  Our server Aishah charming and accommodating.  Beef was tender.  Fried rice spicy and tasty.

Swg4szV-9jAPZPVnCfyq-A.text: Went on a weeknight without reservations. They were fairly full but accommodated. We had the beef rendeng, beef and prawn noodles and satay. Everything was delicious. The rendeng was very spicy, recommend getting plain rice with it because the noodles were spicy too. The chai was good too. We forgot our phone and they kept it for us. We went back for it, we thought it was very nice of them. Would definitely go next time in London!

Fjk5YRL6HSh3X9VQVdoxNA.text: My favourite Malaysian in London!The roti cenai is delicious, and frankly so is everything else on the menu.Now I have never been to Malaysia myself but this place has been recommended to me by 2 Malay friends of mine and I can see (and taste) why.It's also decorated quite nicely. More of a café style upstairs with a restaurant feel downstairs.The service is friendly, it's reasonably priced and although they can get very busy sometimes they do their best to accommodate you.It's relatively centrally located but it's a few minutes' walk from the nearest stations (Edgware Road, Paddington or Marble Arch).Worth a visit if you fancy Malaysian food for sure :)

uCnXOfZA18bU_0yzyOAsfA.text: Exuberantly rich curries and satay sauce, reasonable prices, this is truly a gem in central London

uDiTgzpLypU3sjpGqIdRnA.text: I would have to say this is going on the favourite places to dine out list. Even though it is a small family owned restaurant accompanying about 11 patrons, it does have a long history with authentic taste and flavour. The service was pleasant and the waiting time for the mains was acceptable but suggest ordering entree as they are also worth the experience. Price for the meal was acceptable to me in relation to the quality of the product. Location is quite central and easy to find. Make sure you book in advance and if ordering takeaway, be prepared to wait 30-60mins. That just illustrates how busy and popular it is.

IM0ueSJv1hEl4_JsvCUvxA.text: I knew this was gonna be great. I think it's the neat font on a clean-looking exterior. Oh, and the fact it was listed on a best-Asian-restaurants-in-Paddington article. Loved my Gado Gado - tofu and potato salad drowned in liberal quantities of sweet peanut sauce. My mate enjoyed her Nasi Goreng also. Cute cafe vibes and restaurant-quality grub; Reasonable prices and chirpy staff. Recommend.

R7AARfpisOstoSJhYoXtxA.text: We had the laksa, aubergine and rendang. They laksa was very good, but also the aubergine and the rendang were good. If you're looking for a malaysian restaurants that also serves beer, this is a very good choice.

cDoPsZM3ox06su2BehVh-A.text: Coconut chicken was the best thing we have had in our travels so far. The roti was good though we didn't care for the sauce it came with (we dipped it in the peanut sauce from the satay and the coconut sauce). We would definitely come back.

sx0DjYXnVNdrLvd3SyzSuA.text: If I had just gotten roti I would have rated this place 4 or 5 stars. However, I had ordered a common beef dish recommended by the staff and was disappointed. It was spicy and missed the note of savory which I often would expect in these dishes. I don't ding them for this but they did get my roti order incorrect (I got plain but ordered the egg and scallion) and they also forgot a a part of my order but luckily the staff chased me down the street. These are just basics that shouldn't be a miss. That said, I would give this place another chance - but dine in only and likely a basic dish that can't be messed up (or I assume) bc it smelled delicious. I want to like this place more bc I appreciate small and charming restaurants but I just can't justify due to my meal (beef dish).

NNK2OLg909604vGyvPn5Qw.text: One of the best kari laksas I have had - i normally love to try new things but I just keep having  the laksa here because its too good!

0sdoxT5aZvsnQLpQq1kMgg.text: If there's one sure thing about Malaysian food, it's that you can really re-create it outside Malaysia. There's just too many variables to take into account that can't be recreated in a building, particularly one that has to meet food hygiene and safety standards!This said Satay House is one of the better Malaysian restaurants that tries it's best to recreate the more formal malaysian dining experience that you can get particularly in the capital of Malaysia. The sambals and chilli are not as I remember them, not as spicy and sweeter, but the satay with compressed rice, onion and cucumber were great. As was the coconut rice. Fluffy and not too salty.Each dish had plenty of flavour and the portions were decent. Whilst there is limited seating upstairs, downstairs, we were situated in a quite luxurious booth where there was a nice HD tv screening the football. It wasn't at a perfect angle for the table, but get there early and you'll have some additional entertainment to the company :)

photos.caption: Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Chicken and Lamb Satay with Rice Cubes, Onion, Cucumber and Satay Sauce.
Photo of Satay House - London, United Kingdom. Nasi Lemak

tcP0e6cXzrRtSMqKeM_lmw.text: Classy and delicious.  Went there on the strength of the Yelp reviews and I wasn't let down!  Good service, great food.
